articles.content:
As strikes on alleged drug boats grow, so do questions about their legality and goal 
         By Franco Ordoñez, Ryan Lucas 
        
           Updated Friday, October 24, 2025 • 4:01 PM EDT 
        
        
      

         The U.S. military carried out three more strikes on alleged drug boats this week. Two of those attacks were not in the Caribbean Sea but in the eastern Pacific Ocean, signaling an expansion of the Trump administration's campaign against drug trafficking from South America. Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth posted a video on X of a blue speedboat skipping along the ocean waters before being hit and then bursting into flames. "Just as Al Qaeda waged war on our homeland, these cartels are waging war on our border and our people," Hegseth  wrote in the Wednesday message . "There will be no refuge or forgiveness — only justice." The Pacific strikes represented the eighth and ninth known boat attacks. On Friday, Hegseth announced  an additional strike in the Caribbean , raising the known death toll to 43. The Trump administration has yet to provide public evidence to support its assertions that the individuals on the boats were cartel members and that the vessels were transporting drugs, raising concerns about the legality of the strikes and the real goals of the White House campaign. Prior to the strikes in the Pacific, the U.S. military had been ramping up the number of troops and naval ships in the Caribbean Sea off the coast of Venezuela. On Friday, the Pentagon said the Gerald Ford Carrier Strike Group is being sent to the U.S. Southern Command area of responsibility, which includes the Caribbean.  International law experts say it's an unprecedented amount of military hardware to confront suspected drug boats, which has fueled questions about whether the operation is about countering narcotics trafficking or instead toppling Venezuelan leader Nicolás Maduro. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       "It's such overkill in this naval deployment that there could be no justification if all the United States is trying to do is to attack a couple of small boats and intimidate drug traffickers," said Benjamin Gedan, who led the Venezuela portfolio at the Obama White House. "It's either a bluff meant to scare the pants off the Venezuelan generals and encourage them to rise up and remove the president … or actual preparations for some sort of war with Venezuela." Trump has insisted that he has the legal authority to launch the attacks in international waters, calling it a national security issue to save American lives. During a meeting on Wednesday with NATO Secretary-General Mark Rutte, Trump boasted about the expanded use of force. "They had one today in the Pacific. And the way I look at it, every time I look because it is violent and it is very — it's amazing, the weaponry," he said. "They have these boats that go 45, 50 miles an hour in the water, and when you look at the accuracy and the power. Look, we have the greatest military in the world." He asserted that his actions are saving the lives of tens of thousands of Americans without providing evidence. He also said the U.S. may conduct strikes on land next. "We will hit them very hard when they come in by land," he said. "We're totally prepared to do that. And we'll probably go back to Congress and explain exactly what we're doing when we come to the land." Some lawmakers are raising concerns  The power to declare war rests with Congress, not the White House. After the al-Qaida attacks on Sept. 11, 2001, which killed some 3,000 Americans, Congress passed an authorization for use of military force, granting the president the ability to use the U.S. military against the terrorist group responsible for the attacks. The Trump administration has designated several South and Central American drug cartels and gangs as foreign terrorist organizations, but Congress has not authorized the use of force against them. Lawmakers — Democrats and some Republicans — have expressed concerns that the strikes on suspected drug boats violate domestic and international laws. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       Republican Sen. Rand Paul of Kentucky charged that Trump has set a new precedent of shoot first, ask questions later. "The idea of indiscriminately killing people without knowing their names, without seeing any evidence, without making a formal accusation or without collecting evidence," he said. "It's kind of ironic that we think these people are so dangerous, we're going to kill them without any information." At the White House on Thursday, Trump said he thinks lawmakers will support his administration's efforts, but when asked why he wouldn't just ask Congress for a declaration of war, he said: "I don't think we're going necessarily to ask for a declaration of war. I think we're just going to kill people that are bringing drugs into our country. OK. We're going to kill them. They're going to be, like, dead." The Trump administration has given few specifics about its legal justification for the military strikes other than that the president is taking action under his Article II powers as commander in chief and as a defensive measure. In a notification to Congress last month, the administration said the president has determined that unspecified cartels are nonstate armed groups and that their actions amount to an "armed attack" on the United States. The administration also said Trump has determined that the U.S. is in an armed conflict with nonstate actors — cartels in South America — and that the Defense Department is conducting operations against them pursuant to the laws of armed conflict. Questions about the legality of the strikes  But legal experts say the administration's justification is full of holes. "What this boils down to is the president of the United States asserting a prerogative to kill people based solely on his own say-so," said Brian Finucane, a former legal adviser for the State Department. Finucane, who is now with the International Crisis Group, says the pivotal legal conclusions "are simply reached by executive fiat," thus "making it permissible for the president to engage in premeditated killing." "Outside of armed conflict, there is a word for the premeditated killing of people, and that word is 'murder,'" he said. "And just because the administration puts together this fig leaf of a legal justification does not legitimize these premeditated killings in the Caribbean." It's not just Venezuela that feels targeted. The latest strikes raised particular concerns in Colombia, which has coastlines on both the Caribbean and Pacific. Colombian President Gustavo Petro has accused the U.S. of murder and charged that some of the strikes killed Colombians. Trump responded by announcing that he would stop aid payments to Colombia. "They're not going to get away with it much longer," Trump said on Thursday. "We're not going to put up with it much longer. Colombia is very bad." 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       This week, a group of independent United Nations experts said even if the boats are transporting drugs, as the White House asserts, "the use of lethal force in international waters without proper legal basis violates international law of the sea and amounts to extrajudicial executions." "These moves are an extremely dangerous escalation with grave implications for peace and security in the Caribbean region," wrote the experts, who are appointed by the U.N. Human Rights Council. On Wednesday, Secretary of State Marco Rubio largely listened as Trump sparred with reporters about his legal authority and allowing Congress to weigh in. When Trump turned to his top adviser on foreign policy for his thoughts, Rubio was blunt. "Bottom line, these are drug boats," he said. "If people want to stop seeing drug boats blow up, stop sending drugs to the United States." Claudia Grisales contributed reporting.

articles.title: Ontario Premier Doug Ford Pauses Anti-Tariff Ad After U.S. President Trump Ends Trade Talks
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Ontario Premier Doug Ford announced a pause to a taxpayer-funded anti-tariff advertising campaign that used audio and video from former U.S. President Ronald Reagan’s 1987 radio address on tariffs. The ad, which aired during the first World Series games, prompted U.S. President Donald Trump to end all trade negotiations with Canada, accusing the ad of being a 'fake' and misleading. Trump claimed the ad misrepresented Reagan’s message, and the White House criticized Canada for playing games instead of engaging seriously. Ford defended the ad as a legitimate effort to promote a pro-trade message and maintain dialogue with American citizens. Canadian officials, including Prime Minister Mark Carney, acknowledged the shift in U.S. trade policy and stressed efforts to expand exports outside the U.S. Provincial leaders such as Wab Kinew and David Eby backed Ford’s campaign, while experts like Daniel Béland argued the ad had backfired. Former minister Jason Kenney defended the ad’s authenticity and criticized the Reagan Foundation’s response to Trump’s influence.
keyTakeAways: Ontario Premier Doug Ford paused an anti-tariff ad campaign aired on U.S. television after U.S. President Donald Trump accused Canada of misrepresenting Ronald Reagan’s 1987 radio address about tariffs.
Trump ended all trade negotiations with Canada, claiming the ad was a fake and falsely edited, which escalated trade tensions between the two nations.
The ad campaign, funded by the Ontario government at approximately $75 million CAD ($54 million USD), used direct audio and video of Reagan speaking against tariffs to criticize U.S. tariffs.
Ford stated the ads were intended to spark a conversation about American workers and businesses affected by tariffs, and that they would continue airing during the first two World Series games.

Canadian officials, including Prime Minister Mark Carney, acknowledged the shift in U.S. trade policy and emphasized focusing on what Canada can control, such as expanding exports to non-U.S. markets.
Trump’s White House spokesman Kush Desai criticized the ad as misleading and claimed Canada’s approach was gaming rather than engaging seriously.

Political figures like Manitoba Premier Wab Kinew and British Columbia Premier David Eby supported Ford’s campaign, while experts like Daniel Béland and Jason Kenney questioned its impact and authenticity.
Jason Kenney, former Conservative cabinet minister, defended the ad as an accurate replay of Reagan’s original message and criticized the Reagan Foundation’s leadership under Trump’s influence.

articles.title: This is not your grandmother's 'Hedda'
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Nia DaCosta's film *Hedda* reimagines Henrik Ibsen's classic play *Hedda Gabler* with a bold, modern twist, featuring Tessa Thompson as a mixed-race, ambitious, and manipulative woman navigating 1950s English society. The film centers on Hedda’s schemes to assert power, using irony, music, and gender critique to expose patriarchal structures. Key changes include redefining Eileen's gender and placing the story in a post-WWII context, deepening the conflict with her former lover. The portrayal of Hedda’s race and her relationship with Judge Brack adds layers of social commentary. The film's visual style, music, and performances are praised for their originality and emotional intensity, and DaCosta's work as a Black woman filmmaker marks a significant step in diversifying narrative voices in cinema.
keyTakeAways: Nia DaCosta's film *Hedda* is a modern, feminist reinterpretation of Henrik Ibsen's classic play *Hedda Gabler*, set in 1950s England and featuring a mixed-race protagonist.
Tessa Thompson plays Hedda, a sharp, manipulative, and ambitious woman who uses performance and social manipulation to gain power in a patriarchal society.

The film is notable for its bold reimagining of the original play, including changing Eileen's gender from male to female and placing the story post-WWII, pre-Swinging Sixties, adding depth to the conflict between Hedda and Eileen.
Hedda’s mixed-race identity and outsider status are central to the narrative, shaping her relationships, especially with Judge Brack (Nicholas Pinnock), who is the only one who truly understands her.
The film uses music, particularly Betty Hutton’s songs like 'It's A Man!' and 'It's Oh So Quiet,' as narrative and thematic tools to critique patriarchy and gender roles.
The film was shot at Flintham Hall in Nottinghamshire and features a strong visual and auditory style, with choreography and music that mirror the emotional and structural dynamics of the plot.
DaCosta, a Black woman filmmaker, is recognized as a rare figure in the industry with five feature films in under a decade, each with a distinct tone and thematic focus.

The film is a significant cultural contribution as it centers a Black woman in a historically white, male-dominated literary and cinematic tradition, offering a new lens on power, identity, and agency.

articles.content:
This is not your grandmother's 'Hedda' 
         By Aisha Harris 
        
           Friday, October 24, 2025 • 6:00 AM EDT 
        
        
      

         In  Hedda , an   intoxicating headrush of a film written and directed by Nia DaCosta, party guests are descending upon an English estate when the 1951 Betty Hutton song " It's A Man! " begins playing. The needle drop is brief, but the lyrics you don't hear in the film reveal the song to be a pointed insertion. "If it acts just like it's the boss / When it knows that  you  are, of course … It's a man!" "It's A Man!" is a cheeky ode to the ineptitude of manhood, poking fun at patriarchy's trappings while imploring women to half-heartedly accept them. How fitting for it to soundtrack this spirited take on  Hedda Gabler , about a woman seeking to escape boredom with her bland academic husband by manipulating the affections and interests of everyone in her orbit. Henrik Ibsen's 19th century   play has been adapted for stage and screen many times, providing generations of powerhouse actresses (Ingrid Bergman, Glenda Jackson, Cate Blanchett) with a dastardly title role to play. With DaCosta's interpretation, a slinky and mischievous Tessa Thompson comfortably sashays into that lineage, and the result is a dazzling rendering of caste, lust and ambition in 1950s England. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       This  Hedda's  Hedda stands out from her predecessors, as a mixed-race woman born out of wedlock to the renowned General Gabler. All her father left her when he died were his prized guns and a scant proximity to high society, which will hardly do for someone like Hedda — who, as one character puts it, possesses an "insatiable appetite." To maintain a foothold in the upper echelons, she's married handsome scholar and "dull fool" George Tesman (Tom Bateman), convincing him to go into debt to purchase a grand countryside estate they cannot afford. Naturally, the occasion calls for a fabulous party they cannot afford. DaCosta confines  Hedda  to a roughly 24-hour period, including said party, during which unfolds a wickedly absorbing chain of events. As guests pour into the decadent digs (the film was  shot on the grounds of Flintham Hall  in Nottinghamshire), the married hosts' many worlds — professional, personal, or as is often the case, both — collide consequentially throughout the evening. Hedda's "bohemian" friends mix and mingle with George's stuffy academic cohort; Thea (Imogen Poots), an old schoolmate of Hedda's, crashes the party and finds herself unwittingly ensnared in Hedda's web of machinations. But the most crucial visitor is the formidable Eileen Lövborg (Nina Hoss, a force), Hedda's one-time paramour, and George's present rival for a university position. The women have plenty of unfinished business between them that Hedda is more than eager to exploit, to the most extreme ends. As Hedda, Thompson has a ball being the agent of chaos, asserting her dominance through calculated mannerisms: an affected way of speaking that's vaguely Brit- ish  and calls to mind the Transatlantic accents of classic Hollywood stars like Katharine Hepburn; curt remarks accompanied by her gentle yet potent guiding touch of an arm or shoulder with those white-gloved fingers. The actress understands Hedda is herself doing a  performance , a putting on of airs that seems to have been perfected through years of being an outsider, an act she envisions as a necessary tool for survival. Very rarely does that mask slip and reveal vulnerability, but when it does — it  goes.  Though this façade is apparent to pretty much everyone except the clueless George, her natural magnetism nevertheless allows her to impulsively scheme and play her party guests like a fiddle to get what she wants — to a point. DaCosta's most significant alterations to Ibsen's text serve  Hedda  well. Bending Eileen's gender (previously Ejlert) while setting the events post-World War II but pre-Swinging '60s lends that character's professional aspirations added heft, and puts her in tension with Hedda for reasons stretching beyond that of a mere scorned lover. (The best scenes involve the two women verbally sparring over the life choices each has made.) And Hedda's race is integral to the interplay. Though hardly overstated and rarely commented upon directly, the viewer can infer and understand plenty about her twisted relationship with the acerbic family friend Judge Brack (Nicholas Pinnock). As her closest confidante and another Black person who's managed to accrue some standing among the white elite, he's the only one who truly "gets" Hedda as much as she can be "gotten" — the  Addison DeWitt to her Margo Channing  via dry, scathing observations of Hedda's diabolical behavior, who sometimes, even, goads her on. To choreograph this bumpy night, DaCosta assembles a stellar team that includes cinematographer Sean Bobbitt, production designer Cara Brower, and editor Jacob Secher Schulsinger. They find the beat and make the film dance, sometimes literally: a standout moment finds the revelers swinging in the golden-hued ballroom to a live band playing another Betty Hutton number, " It's Oh So Quiet ," a song that oscillates between a whispered, serene waltz and the explosion of a big, strutting brass band, not unlike the structure and cadence of  Hedda . Suddenly, the music fades to a dim echo but DaCosta's camera keeps swirling close-up on Hedda letting loose, her exerted gasps and breaths amplified. (Those sonic exhalations echo throughout composer Hildur Guðnadóttir's evocative score.) This sequence sets the stage for the seamless transition into the pivotal next act – and presents a visually effective moment which struck me as a possible homage to Spike Lee. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       The filmmaking industry's progress being as slow and nonlinear as it is, DaCosta occupies a rare space as a Black woman filmmaker. Unlike many of her peers and forebears, she's had the opportunity to helm five features in less than a decade, and each has been a totally different vibe: her feature debut  Little Woods , for one, is a quiet and very good indie about a parolee hustling to survive and support her sister in North Dakota (also starring Thompson); her next film is the zombie franchise installment  28 Years Later: The Bone Temple . But  Hedda  suggests DaCosta's at her most creatively free, at least thus far, in this mode. For the viewer, she excavates the pleasures in watching an antiheroine meddle maniacally and unabashedly, spinning a spectacular mess that's impossible to look away from. Hedda may or may not possess any real, tangible power in her day-to-day life. But for a few hours at least, she is the boss. Amazon, which is distributing  Hedda , is a financial supporter of NPR and pays to distribute some of our content.

articles.title: The World Series and the Hidden Persuasion of Drug Ads
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The article critiques the growing trend of pharmaceutical advertising during major sports events like the World Series, where drug companies spend over $895 million annually targeting audiences with chronic conditions such as psoriasis, diabetes, and high cholesterol. Using data from iSpot and expert insight from Dr. Caleb Alexander of Johns Hopkins, the piece highlights how ads often depict idealized lifestyles while subtly linking to conditions like dermatitis, wheezing, and eczema, and then immediately follow with warnings of serious side effects such as myelosuppression and psoriatic arthritis. Despite FDA-mandated disclosures of risks, the article argues that such advertising functions not just as information but as persuasion, potentially influencing patient decisions without full awareness. It concludes with a public health warning: viewers should consult doctors and avoid operating heavy machinery while watching sports, due to the pervasive and persuasive nature of these ads.
keyTakeAways: Direct-to-consumer pharmaceutical advertising during major sports events like the World Series exposes millions of viewers to drug promotions, often targeting conditions like psoriasis, Crohn’s disease, ulcerative colitis, diabetes, obesity, and high cholesterol.
Drug ads frequently showcase idealized lifestyles (e.g., dancing, biking, zip-lining) while subtly hinting at conditions such as dermatitis, dehydration, wheezing, anxiety, and eczema.

Despite FDA regulations requiring 'dual-modality risk statements' — that is, both benefits and potential side effects — these ads are seen as persuasive, possibly influencing patient behavior without full awareness.

Dr. Caleb Alexander of the Johns Hopkins School of Medicine emphasizes that drug advertising is not just information but persuasion, potentially affecting patient decisions and doctor-patient dynamics.

The article advises viewers to consult a doctor before making health-related decisions influenced by such ads and to avoid operating heavy machinery while watching sports due to potential side effects from ads or viewing fatigue.

Opinion: Ask your doctor if the World Series is right for you ... 
         By Scott Simon 
        
           Saturday, October 25, 2025 • 8:00 AM EDT 
        
        
           Heard on  Weekend Edition Saturday 
        
      

         My family and I have been watching post-season baseball, and I think I have to lie down. We've seen so many ads for drugs prescribed to treat plaque psoriasis, Crohn's disease, and ulcerative colitis that I'm sure I've developed a rash, nausea, joint pain and dizziness. Just by watching. iSpot, the TV ad news site, says drug companies bought $895.8 million worth of ads in sports programming last year. The commercials that run during post-season baseball are rife with talk of dermatitis, dehydration, and wheezing. It's almost a relief to see just an ad for beer, or a lizard selling car insurance. "The baseball playoffs are watched by millions," Dr. Caleb Alexander, of the Johns Hopkins School of Medicine Center for Drug Safety and Effectiveness, reminds us. "These games offer drug companies a captive audience, a lot with grey hair, who may have diabetes, obesity, high cholesterol and other common diseases." Prescription drug ads were once banned on broadcasts. But companies argued that infringed on free speech; and the drugs could help people. The FDA now permits pharmaceutical ads, as long as what regulators call "dual-modality risk statements" — possible side effects — are clearly stated. And so you see commercials that show winsome old friends dancing, biking, and shooting down forested zip lines, despite the shadow of psoriasis, insomnia, anxiety or eczema. Then the same soothing voice that advises you to see a doctor for a prescription cautions the medication might also lead you to develop symptoms of myelosuppression, psoriatic arthritis and abdominal swelling. "Medicines are not inherently 'good' or 'bad,'" advises Dr. Alexander. But direct-to-consumer advertising for drugs, he believes, "may drive behavior in ways that patients, and doctors — keep in mind we are watching the baseball games, too — may not even be aware of. It's not just information," notes the doctor. "It's persuasion." And so now, back to baseball. Enjoy the World Series! Dodgers and Blue Jays, sports-betting and beer, auto loans and iPhones. Allergies, high blood pressure, and narcolepsy. Headache, stomach acid and/or facial swelling. Consult a doctor. And do not operate heavy machinery while watching sports!

Prescription drug ads were once banned on broadcast, but companies argued that infringed on free speech, and the drugs could help people. The FDA now permits pharmaceutical ads as long as what regulators call dual modality risk statements - possible side effects - are clearly stated. And so you see commercials that show winsome old friends dancing, biking and shooting down forested zip lines despite the shadow of psoriasis, insomnia, anxiety or eczema. Then the same soothing voice that advises you to see a doctor for a prescription cautions the medication might also lead you to develop symptoms of myelosuppression, psoriatic arthritis and abdominal swelling. Medicines are not inherently good or bad, advises Dr. Alexander, but direct-to-consumer advertising for drugs, he believes, may drive behavior in ways that patients and doctors - keep in mind, we are watching the baseball games too - may not even be aware of. articles.title: Trump Ends All Trade Negotiations with Canada Over Reagan-Quoting Ad
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: In a significant escalation of trade tensions, U.S. President Donald Trump announced the termination of all trade negotiations with Canada following a television advertisement sponsored by Ontario’s government. The ad, which used a quote from former President Ronald Reagan opposing tariffs, was criticized by Trump as a 'crooked' and 'fake' representation of Reagan’s views. The Reagan Presidential Foundation and Institute disputed the ad’s accuracy and claimed it used unapproved edits. Ontario Premier Doug Ford defended the ad, stating it successfully reached U.S. political audiences and achieved its goal. Despite Canada’s Prime Minister Mark Carney’s continued openness to talks, Trump’s decision reflects deeper frustrations over Canada’s trade strategy, especially in light of the U.S. president’s protectionist tariffs and their impact on Canada’s auto sector. The incident also underscores the sensitivity of political messaging involving historical figures and raises concerns about political influence on judicial processes, particularly regarding a Supreme Court hearing on Trump’s tariff authority.
keyTakeAways: President Donald Trump announced the end of all trade negotiations with Canada following a television ad sponsored by Ontario that quoted former President Ronald Reagan to criticize U.S. tariffs.
The ad, which used Reagan's 1987 speech opposing tariffs, was claimed by Trump to be a 'crooked' and 'fake' representation of Reagan’s views, leading to the termination of negotiations.
Ontario Premier Doug Ford defended the ad, stating it successfully reached high-level U.S. audiences and achieved its goal of sparking discussion about tariffs and economic policy.
The Ronald Reagan Presidential Foundation and Institute condemned the ad as a misrepresentation and without proper permission, asserting it misrepresented Reagan’s actual position on tariffs.
Trump claimed the ad was designed to influence the U.S. Supreme Court’s upcoming hearing on his tariff powers, raising concerns about political interference.
Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney reiterated Canada’s readiness to resume trade talks, while noting the U.S. trade policy has fundamentally shifted since the 1980s.
The incident reflects broader tensions between Trump’s protectionist trade policies and Canada’s efforts to promote free trade and economic openness.
The conflict also highlights the sensitivity of using historical political figures, especially Reagan, in political messaging, particularly in cross-border disputes.
Trump’s decision to end negotiations marks a significant escalation in U.S.-Canada trade relations, potentially impacting cross-border trade, especially in the auto sector.
The ad was part of a broader campaign by Ontario, which had planned to spend $54 million (about $75 million Canadian) on television airings, with the highest exposure in New York and Washington, D.C.

articles.title: Conspiracy Theorists Fuel 'Bugonia' Climate Horror
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The article discusses the release of the film 'Bugonia', a psychological thriller directed by Yorgos Lanthimos, which explores the rise of conspiracy theories and societal distrust in a post-truth world. The film centers on Teddy, a conspiracy theorist played by Jesse Plemons, who believes a powerful CEO, Michelle Fuller (played by Emma Stone), is an alien intent on destroying Earth. The film draws on themes of ecological collapse, corporate exploitation, and alienation, using real-world anxieties about misinformation and power. The narrative features a nuanced portrayal of autistic actor Aidan Delbis as Teddy’s cousin, emphasizing authenticity and emotional depth. The film's title and symbolism are rooted in ancient Greek mythology, linking environmental decay to mythological rituals. Shot on vintage VistaVision film stock, it creates a visually striking contrast between intimate scenes and grandeur. Inspired by the South Korean film 'Save the Green Planet!', 'Bugonia' is positioned as a timely and unsettling commentary on modern societal structures, biases, and the spread of false narratives, making it relevant to global concerns about truth and trust.
keyTakeAways: The film 'Bugonia' explores conspiracy theories and societal distrust in a post-truth world, mirroring real-world concerns about misinformation.
Director Yorgos Lanthimos uses the film as a psychological and societal experiment to challenge biases about people and power structures.
The film features a central plot where a conspiracy theorist, Teddy (played by Jesse Plemons), kidnaps a CEO (played by Emma Stone), believing she is an alien working to destroy Earth.
The story draws on real-world issues such as capitalist exploitation, ecological collapse, and alienation, making it relevant to contemporary anxieties.
The film’s title and symbolism — derived from ancient Greek roots meaning 'ox' and 'progeny' — reflect mythological and ecological themes tied to environmental collapse.
Aidan Delbis, playing Teddy's cousin, is autistic and brings a nuanced, authentic perspective to the film, emphasizing inclusive storytelling and sensitivity.
The film's cinematography, shot on vintage VistaVision format, adds a sense of grandeur and depth to intimate, tense scenes, enhancing its unsettling tone.
The film is loosely inspired by the 2003 South Korean film 'Save the Green Planet!', linking it to global environmental concerns and speculative narratives.
Lanthimos emphasizes that the characters represent archetypes but that the film challenges assumptions about truth, power, and human perception.
The film is seen as particularly relevant in an age of misinformation, where audiences are exposed to conflicting realities and echo chambers.

articles.content:
Conspiracy theorists fuel 'Bugonia' climate horror 
         By Leila Fadel, Olivia Hampton 
        
           Friday, October 24, 2025 • 3:43 AM EDT 
        
        
           Heard on  Morning Edition 
        
      

         In  Bugonia , a greasy-haired Jesse Plemons plays conspiracist antihero Teddy, who concludes that his own boss is in fact part of an alien race intent on destroying Earth. So he and his cousin Don kidnap her. It's just the latest absurd offering from director Yorgos Lanthimos, part of what he calls his "little paradigms or experiments" to observe societal constructs and dig into what's behind them. Teddy may appear unhinged, but he has valid reasons to feel angry and afraid — capitalist exploitation, ecological disasters and the sense that society doesn't care about people like him.  So it's no wonder he sets his sights on Emma Stone's ruthless, Louboutin-clad CEO. "Nobody gives a f*** about us," he tells Don, played by Aidan Delbis, who is making his feature film debut at 19. The actor describes himself as autistic. Lanthimos acknowledged that the characters represent archetypes, but all is not as it may seem. The film slowly uncovers layers of complexity.  "It challenges all these biases that we have about people, which is aided by technology and compartmentalization," he told  Morning Edition  host Leila Fadel, referring to those biases as a "dormant" state of mind. The screenplay, by Will Tracy, is loosely based on the 2003 South Korean film  Save the Green Planet! This is not the strangest tale spun by Lanthimos, after previous features explored the extremes of parental control ( Dogtooth ), jealousy and power struggles ( The Favourite ), scientific experimentation ( Poor Things ) or revenge ( The Killing of a Sacred Deer ). But  Bugonia , out in theaters nationwide October 31, feels especially relevant in an era filled with misinformation. The strangely unsettling tale backed by stilted, darkly humorous dialogue also makes for some especially riveting cinema.  The secret lives of bees First, a bit of etymology: the word bugonia that lends the film its name comes from the ancient Greek words for "ox" and "progeny," a reference to a ritual based on the myth that bees emerge from an ox carcass. Bees appear in the opening and closing shots of the film, and Teddy's pastime as beekeeper is part of what fuels his belief that Earth is hurtling toward doomsday. He determines that the hives face colony collapse disorder, which he blames on pollution caused by Auxolit — the company run by Stone's character Michelle Fuller — and on other corporations he believes are run by aliens. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       As the two cousins drive away with a sedated Fuller in her car, Teddy has Don shave off the company executive's hair — to prevent her, he says, from contacting her mothership.  Stone shaved her head for real for the role, her fourth feature film collaboration on a feature film with Lanthimos, which he credits to their "synchronicity." They also worked together on the short film  Bleat  set on the Greek Cycladic island of Tinos. When Fuller wakes up in Teddy's dirty basement, shaven and slathered in an antihistamine cream meant to dull her supposed extraterrestrial powers, Fuller begins a tense negotiation for her release. Making cramped scenes feel grand These cramped scenes still manage to feel grand because Lanthimos shot much of the film on VistaVision, a format that is usually especially desirable for large vistas.  Directors like Brady Corbet ( The Brutalist ) and Paul Thomas Anderson ( One Battle After Another ) have also turned to this vintage format debuted by Paramount Pictures in 1954. Cinematographer Robbie Ryan tracked down a rare Wilcam 11 camera to shoot on Vistavision, which is fed horizontally rather than vertically, resulting in a crisper image than standard 35mm film. "The juxtaposition of filming closeups of faces in a very limited space with that kind of format kind of made them iconic," Lanthimos said. "So all this confrontation between these people is kind of elevated to a different level just by the depth and the tonality that the medium provides." And a note, Focus Features provides financial support to NPR.  The broadcast version of this story was produced by  Phil Harrell  and edited by  Olivia Hampton . The digital version was edited by   Majd Al-Waheidi . 
         
         Transcript 
         A MARTÍNEZ, HOST:   In the new film "Bugonia," Emma Stone plays the CEO of a pharmaceutical bioengineering company. Michelle Fuller is powerful and ruthless. One of her employees is a conspiracy theorist, and his research has led him to the conclusion that she is an alien who wants to destroy planet Earth, and he kidnaps her with help from his cousin. (SOUNDBITE OF FILM, "BUGONIA") EMMA STONE: (As Michelle Fuller) Where is my hair? JESSE PLEMONS: (As Teddy Gatz) Your hair has been destroyed. STONE: (As Michelle Fuller) You shaved off my hair? PLEMONS: (As Teddy Gatz) Yes, we've shaved off your hair. STONE: (As Michelle Fuller) Why have you shaved off my hair? PLEMONS: (As Teddy Gatz) To prevent you from contacting your ship. STONE: (As Michelle Fuller) My ship? PLEMONS: (As Teddy Gatz) Your ship. STONE: (As Michelle Fuller) What ship? PLEMONS: (As Teddy Gatz) Your mother ship. MARTÍNEZ: Our co-host Leila Fadel spoke with director Yorgos Lanthimos. LEILA FADEL, BYLINE: You know, "Bugonia" felt particularly relevant to this sort of fractured, some describe as a post-truth world that so many live in today, with the amount of information and misinformation online. A lot of that is personified in Teddy, who's played by Jesse Plemons. What does he represent in this film? YORGOS LANTHIMOS: Well, that's the thing. I think the structure of the film kind of has you believe that Teddy represents one specific thing that you... FADEL: Yeah. LANTHIMOS: ...You think might immediately recognize. And I think the same is for Michelle, Emma's character. FADEL: The CEO of the company. So Teddy is this kind of menial labor employee at her company, and she's this all-powerful CEO. LANTHIMOS: And you kind of - you know, immediately, they're, like, archetypes and you kind of know who they are and what they represent, and you know, how they think. But I think you realize that things might not be exactly as we thought, and, you know, it challenges all these biases that we have about people in today's society. FADEL: There's a particular scene where Emma Stone in her CEO way - except she's being held in a basement... LANTHIMOS: (Laughter). FADEL: ...Is lecturing her kidnapper. I'm just going to play that scene for you. (SOUNDBITE OF FILM, "BURGONIA") STONE: (As Michelle Fuller) I think you're in a kind of echo chamber. PLEMONS: (As Teddy Gatz) Echo chamber? Right now? STONE: (As Michelle Fuller) Mm-hmm. PLEMONS: (As Teddy Gatz) Echo? Yeah, I read the same 5,000 think pieces about that, too. STONE: (As Michelle Fuller) You're consuming content on the internet that is reinforcing this sort of warped subjective idea of reality. PLEMONS: (As Teddy Gatz) This is your best shot at me, some rabbit hole [expletive] you read in the Times? Come on. Come on. STONE: (As Michelle Fuller) Can we have a dialogue, please? PLEMONS: (As Teddy Gatz) Don't call it dialogue. This isn't "Death Of a Salesman." FADEL: Oh, my gosh, this is such a familiar... LANTHIMOS: (Laughter). FADEL: ...Sort of talking point in the world today. So the one line when he goes, you know, I don't get my news from the news. As a journalist. I was like, oh, no. LANTHIMOS: (Laughter). FADEL: But so true. LANTHIMOS: You have to be thorough. You have to look everywhere. FADEL: Yeah. LANTHIMOS: (Laughter). FADEL: Just walk me through what's... LANTHIMOS: Yeah. FADEL: ...Happening in this scene and why it's so important. LANTHIMOS: You know, at this point, Michelle realizes that, you know, Teddy's way more sophisticated than what she thought. And she realizes, I think that it's not gonna be easy to change his mind... FADEL: Right. LANTHIMOS: ...No matter how crazy it is what he thinks. FADEL: Right. I mean, 'cause Teddy's convinced that he's saving the world. LANTHIMOS: Yeah. FADEL: This is the fourth feature film you've made with Emma Stone after the favorite "Poor Things," and "Kinds Of Kindness." You also made a short film together. What's at the core of your creative partnership? What works about it and keeps this collaboration going? LANTHIMOS: You know, before, you know, I worked with her, I really admire her work as an actor and her presence. And, you know, as soon as we worked together on "The Favourite," we discovered that we get along as people as well, and the way that we work has a lot of synchronicity, and, you know, it just makes it much more pleasurable. And then we also have built a team around us. So it's like a - almost like a theater group that, you know, meets every year or - I mean, lately we've been doing many films back to back, so it's even less than a year. FADEL: The film really focuses on three people, right? So there's Michelle Fuller, there's Teddy, who's the brains behind the kidnapping, and there's also Aidan Delbis, who plays Teddy's cousin, and he's this very sweet, younger cousin who kind of takes whatever Teddy says and believes him. LANTHIMOS: Yeah. And Aidan is autistic. He's - that's the way he prefers to be referred to. I kind of worked with him the same way like I did with Jesse and Emma. I wanted him to bring his very special sensibility and understanding of the world and how he saw the character. FADEL: There's some pretty intense and honestly maybe possibly traumatic scenes. I'm just wondering if working with Aidan, who has maybe different sensitivities, if there was anything else, anything you did differently, or he did differently or he required or asked for. LANTHIMOS: Yeah. I mean, we always had an access coach with him. So... FADEL: Yeah. LANTHIMOS: ...She would walk through everything with him beforehand. And if there was anything that, you know, we felt that was particularly sensitive, we would try and, you know, not involve him as much as we could. But Aidan is like - he loves horror films, and I think he understood, you know, how it functioned. I mean, he's so honest - has no filter. He was like really... FADEL: So he'll just tell you how he feels about everything. LANTHIMOS: Yeah, he'll just tell you. Like, if he gets bored - like with you're trying to explain something and you're mid-sentence, he'd go like, OK, OK, I got it, and he'd walk away. FADEL: (Laughter). LANTHIMOS: Like, it was - yeah, really reinvigorating to have someone like Aidan on set. FADEL: Every time I watch one of your films, I leave feeling, like, extremely uncomfortable with what you've just said about society. I'm like, I don't know if I want to look in this mirror. Why are you drawn to these types of films, this deep, disconcerting examination of who we are? LANTHIMOS: Why? Yeah, that's a good question. FADEL: (Laughter). LANTHIMOS: It's just a natural curiosity for me, like observing, you know, humans, the society, its rules, what's going on in the world and, you know, creating these little paradigms or experiments to reveal more things or ask more questions more than understand things and then, you know, keep going further and further until maybe you'll understand certain things at some point (laughter). MARTÍNEZ: That was Leila speaking with director Yorgos Lanthimos. His new film is called "Bugonia." And a note, Focus Features is a financial supporter of NPR. (SOUNDBITE OF RADIOHEAD SONG, "SUBTERRANEAN HOMESICK ALIEN")

articles.title: Trump Accuses Canada of Misrepresenting Reagan's Views on Tariffs in Trade Ad
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: President Donald Trump pulled out of trade talks with Canada after accusing Ontario’s provincial government of running a fraudulent ad quoting former President Ronald Reagan’s 1987 radio address, in which Reagan criticized tariffs. Trump claimed the ad falsely portrayed Reagan as opposing tariffs, asserting he actually 'loved' them for national security. In reality, Reagan often criticized tariffs and emphasized free commerce, though he did impose them selectively — such as on Japanese semiconductors — to protect U.S. industries. The Reagan Presidential Foundation and Institute clarified that the ad misrepresented Reagan’s views, and experts like Robert Lighthizer and the Cato Institute have noted Reagan’s nuanced, protectionist approach. Trump’s current policy of imposing widespread tariffs — including double-digit rates on nearly every country — has raised concerns about overreach and constitutional authority, with the U.S. Supreme Court set to rule on executive power in trade. The incident highlights a broader debate over the historical context of free trade, the legitimacy of political messaging, and the balance of power between the executive and legislative branches in trade policy.
keyTakeAways: Former U.S. President Ronald Reagan criticized tariffs in a 1987 radio address, stating they hurt American workers and consumers and led to trade wars.
The Canadian provincial government aired an ad quoting Reagan’s 1987 speech, claiming he opposed tariffs — a claim Trump disputed as 'fake' and 'fraudulent'.
Trump accused Canada of cheating by misrepresenting Reagan’s views and claimed the ad was intended to interfere with U.S. trade negotiations and Supreme Court decisions.

The Ronald Reagan Presidential Foundation and Institute clarified that the ad misrepresented Reagan’s actual views and context — Reagan had imposed tariffs for specific reasons, including protecting U.S. industries and responding to trade agreements.
Reagan did not support tariffs broadly; he often criticized protectionist policies and emphasized free commerce, though he did use tariffs selectively in 1987 to protect American industries.
Trump’s current trade policy is characterized by a heavy reliance on tariffs, with an average effective U.S. tariff rate rising from 2.5% in 2025 to 18% — the highest since 1934.
Trump has referred to himself as 'Tariff Man' and has implemented double-digit tariffs on nearly every country and targeted products like steel, autos, and pharmaceuticals.
The U.S. Supreme Court is set to hear arguments about the constitutional authority of the executive branch to levy tariffs, raising legal and constitutional questions about trade policy.

articles.title: Alamo CEO Resigns After Republican State Official Criticizes Her Historical Views
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Kate Rogers, CEO of the Alamo Trust, resigned after Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick publicly criticized her 2023 academic paper, which questioned the state's education policies and proposed a more inclusive narrative of the Alamo's history—including Indigenous presence and slavery’s role in Texas’ independence. The paper, written during her doctorate at the University of Southern California, challenged traditional narratives that depict the Alamo as a '13 Days of Glory' symbol of freedom. Patrick condemned the work as politically incorrect and demanded her resignation, sparking a larger debate over political interference in historical education. The Alamo, a major cultural and tourist site drawing over 1.6 million visitors annually, is set for a $400 million renovation with a new museum opening in 2027, further amplifying the significance of how its story is presented. Critics like Bexar County Judge Peter Sakai argue that political figures should not dictate history education, while others, like Patrick, see it as a threat to national heritage.
keyTakeAways: Kate Rogers, CEO of the Alamo Trust, resigned after Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick publicly criticized her academic paper for challenging the traditional narrative of the Alamo and the state’s education policies.

Patrick criticized Rogers’ work for suggesting the Alamo’s history should include Indigenous presence and the role of slavery, which contradicts his view of it as '13 Days of Glory' and a symbol of freedom.
The conflict reflects a broader national debate over how U.S. history—especially slavery and Indigenous history—should be taught in schools and public institutions.
The Alamo Trust manages the shrine, which draws over 1.6 million visitors annually and is set for a major renovation in 2027 with a new museum that may reflect more inclusive historical narratives.
The resignation underscores the political tension between academic freedom and state control over historical interpretation, especially in education policy.

articles.title: U.S. Stocks Hit Record Highs After Favorable Inflation Report
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: U.S. stock markets hit record highs on Friday, October 24, 2025, following a report showing less painful inflation than previously feared. The S&P 500, Dow Jones, and Nasdaq all surpassed their prior all-time highs, driven by optimism that the Federal Reserve will continue cutting interest rates to stimulate the slowing job market. Stronger-than-expected corporate profits, especially from Ford, Intel, and Google, contributed to the rally. AI-related demand, particularly in computing, is fueling growth in tech stocks. Despite a surge in gold prices, which has raised inflation and debt concerns, the overall market sentiment remained positive. The Federal Reserve is now more focused on labor market conditions than inflation, increasing confidence in upcoming rate cuts. Global markets also rose, with South Korea and Japan seeing significant gains. The article underscores how inflation data, AI innovation, and geopolitical stability are interlinked in shaping global financial markets.
keyTakeAways: U.S. stock markets hit record highs after inflation data showed a less painful rise in prices, boosting investor confidence.
The S&P 500, Dow Jones, and Nasdaq all reached new all-time highs, signaling strong market sentiment.
Lower inflation expectations have led Wall Street to anticipate further rate cuts by the Federal Reserve, particularly at the next two meetings.
Stronger-than-expected corporate profits, especially from tech and auto sectors, contributed to the stock rally.
AI-driven demand, particularly in computing, is boosting demand for tech companies like Intel and Google.
The surge in gold prices has drawn criticism due to rapid gains, with concerns that it may exacerbate inflation and debt issues.
Global markets, including South Korea and Japan, also rose, indicating broader positive sentiment.

articles.title: JPMorgan Chase Challenges $115 Million Legal Fees for Fraud Convicted Startup Founders
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: JPMorgan Chase, after acquiring the fraudulent financial aid startup Frank in 2021, has been covering legal fees for its co-founders Charlie Javice and Olivier Amar, who were convicted of fraud involving false customer data. The bank now claims that the legal bills—totaling $115 million, with one firm receiving $35.6 million—exceed what is reasonable and are part of an abusive billing scheme. The bank argues that its obligation under the original acquisition agreement should end, as the fees are 'patently excessive and egregious,' and that it would be 'irreparably injured' if the court does not intervene. This case is notable because the fees far surpass those in other high-profile fraud cases, such as Elizabeth Holmes’ $30 million bill, and raises broader questions about legal ethics, fee transparency, and the accountability of law firms in fraud-related litigation.
keyTakeAways: JPMorgan Chase has been covering legal fees for Charlie Javice and Olivier Amar, two convicted fraudsters who sold their financial aid startup Frank to the bank in 2021.
Javice's legal team has billed the bank $60.1 million, while Amar's team has billed approximately $55.2 million, totaling $115 million in legal fees.
One law firm received $35.6 million in reimbursements alone, indicating extreme cost concentration and potential abuse.
The bank argues that the fees are 'abusive' and 'excessive,' and that the initial agreement allowing fee coverage should end.
The court has previously ruled that the bank must advance legal fees under the original purchase agreement, which is now being challenged on grounds of abuse.
Alex Spiro of Quinn Emanuel represents Charlie Javice and has previously represented Elon Musk, raising questions about legal representation in high-profile fraud cases.
In comparison, Elizabeth Holmes, convicted in the Theranos case, faced a legal bill of about $30 million, showing that the fees in this case are significantly higher and more controversial.

articles.title: Trump Officials Not Giving Up on Deporting Abrego Garcia to African Nations Despite Resistance
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The U.S. government plans to deport Kilmar Abrego Garcia, a Salvadoran national living in Maryland, to Liberia as early as October 31, 2025, following failed attempts to deport him to Uganda, Eswatini, and Ghana. This action comes after a 2021 mistaken deportation to El Salvador violated a court settlement, prompting legal challenges and public criticism. A Maryland federal judge previously barred immediate deportation, arguing that the Trump administration is using the process as a punitive measure for the embarrassment of the earlier error. Abrego Garcia, who has an American wife and child and faces criminal charges for human smuggling, claims the prosecution is vindictive and illegally motivated. His attorneys argue that the deportation plan is cruel, unconstitutional, and that Costa Rica offers a lawful and humane alternative. The U.S. government justifies the move by citing Liberia’s democratic status and human rights protections, though critics view the plan as politically driven and inhumane.
keyTakeAways: Kilmar Abrego Garcia, a Salvadoran national living in Maryland, was mistakenly deported to El Salvador in 2021, violating a legal settlement, prompting national scrutiny of Trump-era immigration policies.
The U.S. government plans to deport Abrego Garcia to Liberia as early as October 31, 2025, following failed attempts with Uganda, Eswatini, and Ghana.
A federal judge in Maryland previously barred immediate deportation, citing concerns that the Trump administration is using deportation as a punitive measure for the embarrassment of a prior error.
Abrego Garcia has an American wife and child, lived legally in Maryland for years, and is facing criminal charges for human smuggling, claiming the prosecution is vindictive and illegal.
The Department of Homeland Security argues that Liberia is a democratic partner with strong human rights protections, making it a lawful destination for deportation.
Attorney Simon Sandoval-Moshenberg criticizes the deportation plan as cruel, punitive, and unconstitutional, advocating for Costa Rica as a lawful and humane alternative.
Abrego Garcia has filed for asylum in the U.S. and seeks to dismiss smuggling charges on grounds of vindictiveness, asserting the case is politically motivated.

articles.title: Putin Faces Demographic Crisis as Births Hit Record Low in Russia
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: For over two decades, Russia has grappled with a shrinking and aging population, driven by historical losses from World War II, the collapse of the Soviet Union, and ongoing economic and social instability. Despite President Vladimir Putin’s sustained efforts to boost births through incentives like free school meals, 'hero-mother' medals, and state holidays, fertility rates remain critically low at 1.4, well below the replacement level. The war in Ukraine has further disrupted the demographic balance by driving young men abroad and increasing fears about the future. New laws banning abortion promotion and LGBTQ+ activism aim to promote traditional family values, but experts and activists warn that these policies are repressive and may result in unsafe, illegal abortions. Women report avoiding state clinics due to intrusive questions, and despite government incentives, births have not increased significantly. Population data shows a steady decline from 147.6 million in 1990 to 146.1 million in 2024, with a significant proportion of the population now aged 55 or older. Experts emphasize that without broader economic stability and a safe future, even strong policy measures will fail to reverse the demographic decline.
keyTakeAways: Russia's population has declined from 147.6 million in 1990 to 146.1 million in 2024, with the addition of Crimea's population since 2014.
The fertility rate remains critically low at 1.4, below the 2.1 replacement level needed to sustain population growth.
Putin has launched multiple initiatives to encourage childbirth, including free school meals for large families, 'hero-mother' medals for women with 10+ children, and cash incentives for parents.
New laws since 2024 ban the promotion of abortion and 'child-free ideology' and restrict LGBTQ+ activism, aiming to promote traditional family values.
These policies have been criticized as repressive, with experts warning that restricting abortion may lead to illegal and unsafe procedures, increasing maternal and fetal mortality.
Demographic decline is exacerbated by the war in Ukraine, which has led to an exodus of young men and a diminished pool of potential parents.
Women in their 20s and early 30s are scarce due to historical population losses from WWII and the collapse of the Soviet Union, making childbirth particularly difficult.

Despite government incentives, births have not increased significantly, and there is no corresponding rise in fertility, suggesting that economic instability and war-related fears outweigh policy interventions.
Anti-immigration policies and restrictions on migrant access to employment and education are being used to stoke nationalist sentiment, further limiting population growth.
Women often avoid state clinics due to intrusive questions about childbearing, indicating a societal and institutional discomfort with reproductive choice.

articles.title: Tropical Storm Melissa Threatens Caribbean with Catastrophic Rain and Flooding
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Tropical Storm Melissa, currently near stationary in the central Caribbean, is forecast to intensify into a major hurricane by Sunday and bring catastrophic rainfall—up to 35 inches in southwest Haiti and up to 25 inches in Jamaica and the southern Dominican Republic. The storm poses a significant threat due to saturated ground, with forecasters warning of deadly flash flooding, landslides, and prolonged exposure to strong winds. At least three people have died in Haiti, and one has died and one is missing in the Dominican Republic. Authorities in Jamaica, Haiti, and the Dominican Republic have issued evacuation orders, activated emergency shelters, and closed schools and government offices. The U.S. National Hurricane Center and meteorologists like Jamie Rhome and Alex DaSilva have emphasized the storm’s slow movement and the potential for a humanitarian crisis, especially in already vulnerable areas. The storm is the 13th named storm of an above-normal Atlantic hurricane season, raising concerns over growing climate-related risks in the Caribbean region.
keyTakeAways: Tropical Storm Melissa is nearly stationary in the Caribbean and poses a serious threat due to its slow movement and heavy rainfall.
The storm could strengthen into a major hurricane, with potential Category 4 status, and is forecast to bring up to 35 inches (89 cm) of rain to southwest Haiti.
Up to 25 inches of rain is expected in Jamaica, southern Haiti, and the southern Dominican Republic, increasing flood and landslide risks.
At least three people were killed in Haiti and one person was killed and one reported missing in the Dominican Republic due to the storm’s impacts.
The U.S. National Hurricane Center warns of catastrophic flash flooding and landslides in Haiti and Jamaica, especially due to saturated ground from prior rains.
Jamaica has activated over 650 shelters, closed schools and government offices, and evacuated vulnerable populations in preparation.
The Dominican Republic experienced significant damage, including 200 damaged homes, loss of water supply for over half a million people, and mandatory evacuations in affected communities.
The storm is the 13th named storm of the Atlantic hurricane season, which is forecast to be above normal in activity.
Residents across the region are expressing concern about safety, with many lacking shelter and resources due to prior gang-related displacement and flooding.

articles.title: Thousands evacuate Philippine coast as Tropical Storm Fengshen approaches
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: As Tropical Storm Fengshen approaches the Philippine coast, over 9,000 residents of Catanduanes have evacuated due to warnings of coastal flooding from waves up to 1.2 meters high. This evacuation follows a recurring pattern where Catanduanes is often the first landmass hit by Pacific cyclones. Title: Thousands evacuate Philippine coast as Tropical Storm Fengshen approaches

Thousands of residents of a Philippine island have fled their homes along the Pacific coast as weather experts warned of coastal flooding ahead of the approach of Tropical Storm Fengshen, rescue officials said.

The eye of the storm was forecast to brush past Catanduanes, an impoverished island of 270,000 people, later on Saturday with gusts of up to 80km/h (50mph).

Fengshen will bring heavy rainfall, along with a “minimal to moderate risk” of coastal flooding from 1.2-metre (3.2-foot) waves being pushed ashore, the government weather service said.

More than 9,000 residents of Catanduanes moved to safer ground, the provincial disaster office said, in an often-repeated drill on the island that has previously been the first major landmass hit by cyclones that form in the western Pacific Ocean.

The Catanduanes provincial government ordered local officials to “activate their respective evacuation plans” for residents of “high-risk areas”, including the coast, low-lying communities and landslide-prone slopes, rescue official Gerry Rubio told the AFP news agency.

The Philippines is hit by an average of 20 storms and typhoons each year, striking disaster-prone areas where millions of impoverished people live.

Scientists warn that storms are becoming more powerful as the planet warms due to human-driven climate change.

Fengshen comes as the country is still reeling from a series of major earthquakes and typhoons that killed dozens of people in recent weeks.

Earlier this month, at least 79 people were killed in a  magnitude 6.9 earthquake  in Cebu province in the central Philippines.

Days later,  another earthquake  struck, this time a magnitude 7.4 off the coast of the southern Philippines, killing at least six people and triggering a second, magnitude 6.9 quake later in the day. Tsunami warnings were issued after each earthquake.

In late September, several people were killed and thousands were evacuated from villages and schools in the northern Philippines, while offices were closed, as Typhoon Ragasa struck.

Title: Trump torpedoes international deal to reduce shipping emissions

Members of the International Maritime Organization (IMO) have voted to postpone approving a plan to curb shipping emissions, after United States President Donald Trump threatened to impose sanctions on countries that supported the measure.

The vote on Friday set back plans to regulate the shipping industry’s contributions to climate change by at least 12 months, even though the Net Zero Framework (NZF) had already been approved by members of the London-based IMO, a United Nations body,  in April .

The decision to formally delay adopting the framework until late next year came a day after President Trump took to his Truth Social platform, saying: “I am outraged that the International Maritime Organization is voting in London this week to pass a global Carbon Tax.”

“The United States will NOT stand for this Global Green New Scam Tax on Shipping,” he said, telling countries to vote against the plan.

Washington also threatened to impose sanctions, visa restrictions and port levies on countries that supported the deal.

In advance of this week’s meeting in London, about 63 IMO members who had voted for the plan in April were expected to maintain their support for curbs on emissions, and others were expected to join the initiative to formally approve the framework.

Following Trump’s social media threat, delegates in London instead voted on a hastily arranged resolution to push back proceedings on the matter, which passed by 57 votes to 49.

The IMO, which comprises 176 member countries, is responsible for regulating the safety and security of international shipping and preventing pollution on the high seas.

Since returning to power in January, Trump has focused on reversing Washington’s course on climate change, encouraging fossil fuel use by deregulation, cutting funding for  clean energy projects  and promising businesses to  “drill, baby drill”.

A spokesman for UN chief Antonio Guterres called Friday’s decisions “a missed opportunity for member states to place the shipping sector on a clear, credible path towards net zero emissions”.

The International Chamber of Shipping, representing more than 80 percent of the world’s fleet, also expressed disappointment.

“Industry needs clarity to be able to make the investments needed to decarbonise the maritime sector,” the chamber’s Secretary-General Thomas Kazakos said in a statement.

Disappointed, but still very much Committed!  https://t.co/7P192kAvCx

— Thomas A. Kazakos (@ThomasKazakos)  October 17, 2025

Ralph Regenvanu, the minister for climate change for Vanuatu, said the decision to delay the vote by 12 months was “unacceptable given the urgency we face in light of accelerating climate change”.

“But we know that we have  international law  on our side and will continue to fight for our people and the planet,” Regenvanu added.

Leading up to Friday’s decision, China, the European Union, Brazil, Britain and several other members of the IMO had reaffirmed their support.

Countries that opposed the measures included  Russia  and Saudi Arabia.

A Russian delegate described the proceedings as “chaos” as he addressed the plenary on Friday after talks had lasted into the early hours.

Argentina and Singapore, two countries that had previously voted in support of the framework in April, were among those that voted to postpone introducing it this week.

If it had been formally adopted this week, the Net Zero Framework (NZF) would have been the first global carbon-pricing system, charging ships a penalty of $380 per metric tonne on every extra tonne of CO2-equivalent they emit while rewarding vessels that reduce their emissions by using alternatives.

The framework plan is intended to help the IMO reach its target of cutting net emissions from international shipping by 20 percent by 2030 and eliminating them by 2050.

Climate change is already beginning to affect shipping and the safety of seafarers, including by changing  ocean currents  and causing more frequent and  severe storms .

Proposals to reduce reliance on dirtier bunker fuel in the shipping industry include using ammonia and methanol, as well as fitting cargo ships with special sails.

Title: UN pushes for worldwide disaster alerts as extreme weather ‘spirals’

Nearly half of all countries lack early-warning systems for extreme weather events, leaving millions – especially those in developing nations – vulnerable.

As it released a new report on Monday, the UN’s World Meteorological Organization (WMO) called for gaps in global monitoring and forecasting networks to be plugged. Timely alerts are crucial to saving lives as extreme weather events multiply due to climate change, it warned.

“Many millions of people lack protection against dangerous weather, which is inflicting an increasing toll on economic assets and vital infrastructure,” said a statement by the WMO, noting that disaster-related deaths are six times higher in countries without early-warning systems.

The organisation said weather, water and climate-related hazards have killed more than 2 million people in the past 50 years. It added that 90 percent of those deaths occurred in developing countries.

“Impacts are spiralling as weather becomes more extreme,” it said.

The WMO acknowledged that there has been “huge progress” in climate monitoring over the last decade. The number of countries using some form of multi-hazard early warning systems has jumped from 52 to at least 108.

However, it continued, an assessment of 62 countries showed half of them possess only basic capacity and 16 percent have less than basic capacity.

“The situation is worst in fragile, conflict and violence-affected contexts,” the organisation said.

Nevertheless, the WMO is seeing progress in Africa, with more countries having functioning websites and issuing standardised alerts.

“Early warning means early action. Our goal is to not only warn the world; it is to empower it,” WMO Secretary-General Celeste Saulo said in a speech as the UN institution opened its annual conference in Geneva on Monday.

The world has been rocked by numerous weather-related disasters in 2025. Huge  flooding has rocked countries including Pakistan ,  Nigeria  and  South Korea . Wildfires have devastated large areas in  southern Europe , as well as  the US .

The head of Switzerland’s Federal Department of Home Affairs, Elisabeth Baume-Schneider, told delegates at the conference that no country or region was spared from the effects of climate change and extreme weather.

She pointed to the example of how the regular monitoring of a mountain glacier allowed scientists to warn about its imminent collapse in May 2025, allowing for the evacuation of the Swiss village of Blatten.

“Permafrost melt will inevitably lead to more glacier collapses and rockfalls,” making early warning systems vital, she said.

articles.title: DOJ Prepares to Deploy Federal Election Observers in California and New Jersey
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The U.S. Department of Justice is preparing to deploy federal election observers to Passaic County, New Jersey, and five California counties—Los Angeles, Orange, Kern, Riverside, and Fresno—ahead of off-year elections on November 4, 2025. The move follows formal requests from Republican parties in both states, citing concerns about irregularities and fraud, particularly in areas with high mail-in voting. The elections are politically significant: California’s vote will determine redistricting that could add Democratic seats to the U.S. House, while New Jersey’s governor’s race features a competitive race in a historically Democratic but now shifting county. Democratic leaders and legal experts have criticized the DOJ’s intervention as inappropriate and politically motivated, arguing that federal agencies lack standing to monitor state-only elections. The DOJ maintains that its actions are rooted in ensuring transparency and compliance with federal civil rights laws, though experts note that such observers do not interfere with voter participation or election outcomes if they follow strict protocols. The broader context includes longstanding claims by former President Donald Trump about widespread election fraud, which have fueled national debates over election integrity.
keyTakeAways: The U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) is planning to send federal election observers to Passaic County, New Jersey, and five California counties (Los Angeles, Orange, Kern, Riverside, and Fresno) ahead of off-year elections on November 4, 2025.

The DOJ’s decision follows formal requests from Republican parties in both states, citing concerns about irregularities and potential fraud, especially in areas with historically high mail-in voting or political shifts.
The primary motivation for the monitoring is to ensure transparency, ballot security, and compliance with federal law, particularly in light of past allegations and political tensions.

California’s election is focused on a redistricting initiative that would add Democratic seats to the U.S. House, countering Republican gerrymandering, while New Jersey’s election features an open governor’s race in a politically competitive county.

Democratic leaders, including New Jersey Attorney General Matt Platkin and California officials, have criticized the DOJ’s move as inappropriate and an intimidation tactic, arguing that the DOJ lacks standing to intervene in state-only elections.

The DOJ has historically monitored elections in jurisdictions with voting rights violations, but the current actions are seen as politically charged due to the timing and the national political climate.

The DOJ’s Civil Rights Division, led by Harmeet Dhillon, will oversee the deployment of observers and work with state and local officials, though experts argue that such observers do not affect voter turnout or election integrity if they do not interact with voters or ballots.

The broader context includes former President Donald Trump’s long-standing false claims about election fraud and his opposition to mail-in voting, which have fueled ongoing political debates about election integrity.

articles.title: Tropical Storm Melissa takes aim at Caribbean, islands on alert
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Tropical Storm Melissa, the first named storm of the 2025 Atlantic hurricane season to form in the Caribbean, poses significant threats to multiple islands including Jamaica, Haiti, the Dominican Republic, Aruba, and Puerto Rico, with heavy rainfall predicted—up to 12 inches in Jamaica’s east—leading to risks of flooding and landslides. The storm, moving slowly westward, is expected to intensify into a hurricane by Friday and a major hurricane by the late weekend. Officials from Jamaica’s Meteorological Service and the U.S. National Hurricane Center are monitoring the situation, urging residents in flood-prone areas to evacuate. Heavy rains have already disrupted daily life in the Dominican Republic, and the broader context of an above-normal hurricane season, as forecasted by NOAA, underscores the increased vulnerability of the region to such storms.

Jamaica’s eastern region could see up to 12 inches (300mm) of rain, which is significant and a primary concern for officials.

Heavy rain is forecast for western Jamaica, southern Hispaniola, Aruba, and Puerto Rico.
Melissa has maximum sustained winds of 50mph (85km/h) and is moving west at 2mph (4km/h), centered about 335 miles south-southwest of Port-au-Prince and 295 miles south-southeast of Kingston.
The storm could strengthen gradually, becoming a hurricane by Friday and a major hurricane by the late weekend.
Melissa is the 13th named storm of the Atlantic hurricane season and the first named storm to form in the Caribbean this year.

Title: Tropical Storm Melissa takes aim at Caribbean, islands on alert

Tropical Storm Melissa is threatening the Caribbean Sea islands with dangerous landslides and life-threatening flooding, as officials urge residents of flood-prone areas to seek higher ground and shelter.

Jamaica’s eastern region could see up to 12 inches (300mm) of rain. “Now that is significant rainfall, and that is the main thing that we should be mindful of at this time,” Evan Thompson, director of Jamaica’s Meteorological Service, said.

Similar rainfall amounts were expected for southern Haiti and the southern Dominican Republic through Saturday, with even more rain possible locally, depending on Melissa’s path later in the week.

Heavy rain was also forecast for western Jamaica, southern Hispaniola, Aruba and Puerto Rico.

Melissa had maximum sustained winds of 50mph (85km/h) and was moving west at 2mph (4km/h) late on Wednesday night, according to the US National Hurricane Center in Miami.

The slow-moving storm was centred about 335 miles (535km) south-southwest of Port-au-Prince, Haiti, and some 295 miles (475km) south-southeast of Kingston, Jamaica.

The NHC said the storm could strengthen gradually in the coming days and grow into a  hurricane  by Friday and a major hurricane by the late weekend.

Heavy rains in the Dominican Republic have already disrupted traffic and led to the cancellation of sports events.

Melissa is the 13th named storm of the Atlantic hurricane season, and the first named storm to form in the Caribbean this year.

The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration predicted an above-normal Atlantic hurricane season – which runs from June 1 to November 30 – with 13 to 18 named storms.

Of those, five to nine were forecast to become hurricanes, including two to five major hurricanes, which pack winds of 111mph or greater.

articles.title: Canadians pull Reagan advertisement after furious Trump halts trade talks
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Ontario Premier Doug Ford announced the suspension of a US advertising campaign featuring quotes from former President Ronald Reagan’s 1987 trade speech, which warned against high tariffs and retaliation from foreign countries. The ad was launched to oppose American tariffs on Canada and reached high-level US audiences. However, it triggered a sharp diplomatic reaction when Donald Trump terminated all trade negotiations, calling the campaign 'fake' and accusing it of misrepresenting Reagan. After discussions with Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney, Ford paused the ad to allow trade talks to resume, though it will continue to air during the upcoming baseball World Series. The Ronald Reagan Foundation criticized the use of 'selective audio and video,' and Trump expressed 'extreme displeasure' over the ad’s removal. A meeting between Trump and Carney is expected at the APEC summit in South Korea as a potential path toward resolving the trade dispute.

The ad used a quote from Reagan’s 1987 radio address warning against high tariffs leading to trade wars.

Trump expressed 'extreme displeasure' over the ad and its removal, with plans to meet with Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney at an APEC summit in South Korea.
The ad aimed to convey that tariffs can harm American workers and businesses, and that economic cooperation is essential for prosperity.
